desc.quote: City in the historical region of Syria (today in Turkey).
As the birthplace of Christianity and the main destination of pilgrimage, Jerusalem played an important role for Christians of all Syr. traditions.

place.placeName: Karka d-Beth Slokh — ܟܪܟܐ ܕܒܝܬ ܣܠܘܟ

desc.quote: The name occurs in the 6th cent. ‘History of Karka d- Beth Slokh and its Martyrs’ published by Bedjan, and it means literally 'Fortress of the House of Seleucus.'

One of the earliest Hellenistic city foundations in Syria, Apamea, situated on the Orontes ca. 90 km. south of Antioch, from the 2nd cent. onwards was an important center of Middle- and Neo-Platonist philosophy.
A small town located between the Tigris and the Upper Zab, some 15 km. southeast of Mosul, between Barṭelle and Qaraqosh.

place.desc: An ancient town in southern Iraq.
One of the biblical rivers coming out of Eden in Genesis 2
A Roman province including the Sinai peninsula and Roman territory east of the Jordan River.

desc.quote: Capital of modern Kurdistan, in eastern Iraq.
City in upper Mesopotamia and important center of Syriac Christianity, especially for the Syr. Orth. Church as the city closest to Dayr al-Zaʿfarān, the seat of the patr. from 1293 until 1932.
City in eastern Anatolia, located near the right bank of the Euphrates and to the north of the main range of the Eastern Taurus.

Principal town of Ṭur ʿAbdin, situated at the geographical center of the region where the main east-west road from Mardin to Gozarto (Cizre) and the north-south road from Ḥesno d-Kifo (Hasankeyf) to Nisibis meet.
City in the north of Iraq, on the west bank of the Tigris opposite the ruins of ancient Nineveh.

place.desc: An ancient port on the coast of Phoenice, and the last Crusader foothold in the Levant.

desc.quote: City in Mesopotamia and important center of early Syriac Christianity.
A very ancient city in northern Iraq located on the eastern side of the Tigris River, directly across from the medieval and modern city of Mosul.

place.desc: The papal city-state since the 1929 Lateran Treaty.
A monastery of unknown location where Rabbula of Edessa was a monk.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Isḥaq — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܝܣܚܩ
place.desc: A monastery at al-Jabbūl near Aleppo.
A Roman province in southeastern Europe.
A Roman province in northern Anatolia
A monastery where Barloho was a monk.
A monastery dedicated to the Virgin Mary located on the Black Mountain.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Tumo — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܬܐܘܡܐ

place.desc: The location of Dayro d-Mor Tumo, perhaps identical with another Seleucia.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Rumanos — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܪܘܡܐܢܘܣ
Dayro d-Qadisho Shemʿun — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܫܡܥܘܢ

place.desc: A port city in Syria, modern Ṭarṭūs.
A city of the Nile delta.
The island of Lesbos in the north Aegean Sea.
A city of Jazīra near modern Abu Kamāl.

place.placeName: Monastery of the Virgin — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܒܬܘܠܬܐ
place.desc: A monastery near the village of Sidus.

place.placeName: Church of the Virgin — ܥܕܬܐ ܕܒܬܘܠܬܐ

place.desc: A castle between Sinjar and Mosul.
An unlocated monastery, perhaps near Maypherqaṭ.
Part of the western side of Baghdad.

place.placeName: Dayr Mār Atūnūs — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܬܢܘܣ
place.desc: An unlocated monastery, perhaps near Melitene.
A city on the Seyhan River in south-eastern Anatolia, near the Mediterranean coast.
An unlocated monastery, perhaps near ʿĀnah.
A place east of the Khabur river in Jazira.

place.placeName: Mor Yuḥanon d-Qurdis — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܕܩܘܪܕܝܣ

place.desc: A place whose inhabitants received a letter from Ḥabīb b. Khidma Abū Rāʾiṭa.
The site of a Syrian Orthodox synod in 807/8.
The location of an addressee of canons from Yaʿqub of Edessa.
A large village in the plain of Mosul.
A village near the Monastery of Qenneshre.
An unlocated village, the birthplace of Sabrway.

place.placeName: St. John the Baptist — ܗܝܟܠܐ ܡܪܝ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܡܥܡܕܢܐ
Dayro d-Arʿo Rabto — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܐܪܥܐ ܪܒܬܐ

place.desc: A monastery mentioned by Yuḥanon of Ephesus.
An island off the western coast of Asia Minor.
A monastery of unknown location where Paulos of Beth Ukome was detained.
An island off the south-western coast of Asia Minor.
A group of settlements including Ctesiphon, Seleucia, and Kokhe.
An ancient and medieval port on the coast of Cilicia.

desc.quote: Town in the Qalamun mountains, Syria, ca. 95 km. northeast of Damascus and less than 20 km. north of Nabk (see Dayr Mār Mūsā al-Ḥabashī), often mentioned as a caravan station between Ḥimṣ and Damascus.

The Chaldean monastery of Rabban Hormizd, built upon a mountain ridge northeast of Alqosh in northern Iraq, is famous not only for its magnificent location and impressive buildings, but also for its central role in the history of the transmission of E.-Syr. literature and its importance in the struggles between the Chald. Church and the Ch. of E., to which the monastery originally belonged.

place.desc: A town on the northwestern coast of Lake Van in eastern Anatolia.

desc.quote: City on the Khabur, located in the eastern part of ancient Osrhoene and today straddling the Turkish-Syrian border, the Syrian part now bearing the name Raʾs al-ʿAyn and the Turkish part Ceylanpınar (earlier Resülayn).

place.desc: A location half an hour away from Rabban Hormizd monastery.

desc.quote: City in northern Syria and an important center of Christianity in the Middle East today as the seat of a total of nine bishoprics.

place.desc: A Roman city on the Cilician coast.

desc.quote: Located on the Tigris, south of modern Baghdad.
A city in eastern Turkey, southwest of Lake Van.
Town 40 km. north of Mosul in Iraq.
Tagrit is a modern city located on the west bank of the Tigris, almost mid-way between Mosul and Baghdad.

Town 15 km. north of Mosul, it is a populous Chald. settlement, seat of a bishopric., with a conspicuous diaspora in Iraq (Mosul, Baghdad, Baṣra, etc.) as well as in the USA, especially in San Diego and Detroit.

place.desc: A town in the mountains of northern Iraq, east of the Tigris.
The eastern major river of Mesopotamia, flowing from SE Turkey to the Persian Gulf.

desc.quote: Urmia (Urūmiyya, Rīzāya), a city in northwest Iran, west of Lake Urmia, is first mentioned in E.-Syr. sources in 1111, whereas the mentioning of bishops in Azerbaijan (Hoshaʿ of Ganzak in 486, Ḥenanishoʿ in 605), testify to earlier presence of the Ch. of E. in this region.
Large Sasanian city on the eastern bank of the Euphrates, the ruins are near present-day Falluja, ca. 60 km. west of Baghdad.
City in Syria.
Syr./Hebrew Ḥārān; Latin Carrhae; Arabic Ḥarran. Ancient city in Mesopotamia, approximately 45 km south-southeast of Edessa.
Ancient city near the Euphrates to the southeast of present-day al-Najaf.

place.desc: An ancient town east of the Jordan River, now the capital of Jordan.

desc.quote: Properly speaking, Ṭur ʿAbdin (‘Mountain of the servants’) does not include the whole province of Mardin in Turkey, but only the limestone plateau in the eastern part of it, between the river Tigris and Nisibis."
This famous monastery was founded in 595/6 by Yaʿqub, a monk of the 'Great Monastery' of Abraham of Kashkar (on the mountain of Izla), who originated from Lashom in Beth Garmai.

The monastery, situated in the mountains to the southeast of Melitene and named after the 5th-cent. ascetic Barṣawmo, rose to prominence as the regular residence of Syr. Orth. Patriarchs in the 11th-13th cent., the period often referred to as the Syriac Renaissance.
Situated ca. 36 km. southeast of Mosul, Dayro d-Mor Behnam contains the only full program of medieval church decoration that survives to this day in Iraq.
The Monastery of Qarṭmin began long before its official foundation date of 397.
Located on the Alfof Mountain, known in Arabic as Jabal Maqlūb, 35 km. northeast of Mosul, the monastery is mostly known by its Arabic name Dayr Mār Mattā.

place.placeName: Musa al-Ḥabashi — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܡܘܫܐ ܟܘܫܝܐ

desc.quote: The Monastery of Moses the Ethiopian is perched on top of a steep, rocky promontory that juts out of a deep gully between two cliffs in the high region south of Nabk.
The Qarqaphto (‘Skull’) Monastery was located near the town of Magdal on the Khabur river southeast of Reshʿayna, in the Jazīra region of Syria.

A W.-Syr. monastery that in its heyday (6th–9th cent.) stood out as a center of Greek study in the Syriac-speaking Near East and which played a key role in the transmission of Greek learning into Syriac.
The name refers to the tip of a height dominating the towns of Darʿūn and Ḥarīṣa, located some 25 km. to the northeast of Beirut.
The Monastery of Tell ʿAda, also known as the ‘Great Monastery’, is located just over 48 km. from Aleppo; 1500 m. north of the present village of Tell ʿAda.

place.desc: A town east of the Tigris and north of the Great Zab in northern Iraq.
A region in the Hakkari mountains.
A region in the Hakkari mountains.
A region in the Hakkari mountains.
A city in the Hakkari mountains.

desc.quote: A small town located some 20 km. to the southeast of Mosul on the road that links this ciy with Arbela and on which Karamlish and Qaraqosh are also found.
A sizable town located to the east of Mosul, on the same road along which Barṭelle and Karamlish are located.
Bahdeidat is 12 km. northeast of Jbeil (Giblet or Byblos), 47 km. from Beirut, 550 m. above sea level.
The village of Maʿad is 14 km. northeast of Byblos (Jbeil), 52 km. from Beirut, 525 m. above sea level.
The town of Eddé lies in the foothills of Mount Lebanon, above the town of Batrun (Botrom).
Village in Lebanon, on the right bank of the Nahr al-Jaouz, ca. 15 km. from Batrun.
Greek Orthodox monastery in Lebanon, known as Dayr Saydat Kaftun (Monastery of Our Lady of Kaftun) and located in the valley of the Nahr al-Jaouz near Kaftun, to the south of Amyūn.

The town of Amyūn is situated 20 km. south of Tripoli (Northern Lebanon), on the road between Chekka and Kousba, built on a high, rocky cliff rising above the plains of olives and fruit orchards watered by the Qadisha river.

place.desc: A Hellenistic city near Apamea, now called al-Rastan.
A monastery beside the village of Qara.
A monastery between Nabk and Qara in Syria.
A river of eastern Anatolia which flows from north of Lake Van into the Euphrates above Melitene.
A mountainous region southeast of Lake Van.

desc.quote: Ecclesiastical province extending from Beth Zabdai northward, Balad southward, and Nisibis westward, the latter being its capital city.
Ecclesiastical province of the Ch. of E., situated in Central Iraq.
An ecclesiastical province confined between the Lower Zab northward, the Tigris westward, the Diyālā river southward, and the mountains of Ḥimrīn eastward.

place.placeName: Dayr Abū Ghālib — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܐܒܘ ܓܐܠܒ

place.desc: A diocese of the Church of the East, also known as Elam, centered around Beth Lapaṭ.

place.placeName: Mor Eusebios of Kaprā d-Bartā — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܘܣܝܒ
Dayro d-Beth Botin — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܒܝܬ ܒܬܝ̈ܢ

place.desc: A monastery between Aleppo and the Euphrates.

desc.quote: Chief city of Beth Huzaye/Khuzistan, whose metropolitan bishopric ranked second after that of Seleucia-Ctesiphon.

place.placeName: Mor Daniel of Jolsh — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܕܢܝܐܝܠ ܕܓܠܫ ܥܢܘܝܐ

desc.quote: An E.-Syr. bishopric seat the heartland of which was the region extending from the small Khabur river to the Tigris, including the area of modern Zakho and part of Dehok.
Monastery situated halfway between Cairo and Alexandria in Wadi al-Natrun, ancient Scetis, Egypt.
The Monastery of St. Catherine on Sinai was founded in the 6th cent. It had a multicultural community prior to the Ottoman period when it became entirely Greek.

The region known in Syriac as Beth Qaṭraye includes not only the peninsula of Qaṭar, but also its hinterland Yamāma, and the entire coast of northeast Arabia as far as the peninsula of Musandam, in present-day Oman, along with the islands.

place.placeName: Monastery of Prophet Elijah — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܩܢܩܪܬ
place.desc: A monastery near Qanqart about 8 km. southwest of Amid.

place.placeName: St. Mark — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܡܪܩܘܣ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܣܛܐ ܘܕܡܪܬܝ ܡܪܝܡ

placeName.reg: ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܡܪܩܘܣ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܣܛܐ ܘܕܡܪܬܝ ܡܪܝܡ

place.placeName: ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܡܪܩܘܣ ܐܘܢܓܠܝܣܛܐ ܘܕܡܪܬܝ ܡܪܝܡ

desc.quote: Said to be located on the site of the Last Supper and named after the Evangelist, the monastery is situated on mount Zion in Jerusalem.

place.placeName: Mor Ahrun d-Shagre — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܗܪܘܢ ܕܫܓܪ̈ܐ
Mor Yaʿqub Malpono — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܥܩܘܒ ܡܠܦܢܐ
Yoḥannan Urṭaya — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܕܐܘܪ̈ܛܝܐ

desc.quote: City in the Ḥawrān, present-day southern Syria, ca. 120 fan. south of Damascus.

place.placeName: Mor Yuḥanon d-Norab — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܕܢܐܪܒ

desc.quote: City on the Tigris, approximately 35 km. north of Seleucia-Ctesiphon.

Balad, Assyrian Balaṭ, Syriac and Arabic Balad or Balaṭ, and modern Aski Mosul (Turkish for ‘Old Mosul’) are names referring to a town located some 40 km. northwest of Mosul, on the west bank of the Tigris.

place.desc: A tributary of the Euphrates that enters it at al-Raqqa.

desc.quote: Beirut, Lebanon is mentioned in many Syr. Orth. texts in connection with the St. Jude monastery and church.
City in S. Arabia (Syr. Nagran, or Negran; Arab. Najrān), and city in Iraq.

place.desc: A village southwest of Mardin, near Kfartuto.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Yaʿqub — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܥܩܘܒ ܡܠܦܢܐ

desc.quote: One of the centers of the Assyrian diaspora in the USA.
it remains uncertain when Christians first reached the main, historically Chinese-speaking (Han), part of China.
A monastic district southwest. of Alexandria (Egypt) on the coastal road to Cyrene (Libya) which flourished esp. in the 5th to 7th cent.
Himyar is the name of a geographical area in southwest Arabia as well as that of a tribal confederation in power from the 1st cent. BC to ca. AD 525.
Also known as Veh-Ardashir or New Seleucia. Located on the Tigris, south of modern Baghdad, the name Kokhe is Aramaic in origin.

The School of Nisibis was an E.-Syr. institution of learning founded in part by refugees from the School of Edessa after the latter was forcibly closed by the religious and political authorities in 489, because it had become an exegetical circle of dyophysite Christians whose Antiochene theology was no longer welcome in a Roman Empire split by Christological controversy.
A prestigious Roman Catholic theological seminary in Mosul, Iraq, called Séminaire Syro-Chaldéen St. Jean in French.
German excavations (1904–7), conducted near Bulayıq, north of Turfan, brought to light numerous fragmentary mss. evidently from the library of an E.-Syr. monastery.
Ancient Chinese city in Shanxi Province.

place.desc: An ancient city where Jacob of Serugh was bishop.

place.placeName: Qaṣr Ibn Hubayra — ܩܨܪܐ ܕܒܪ ܗܘܒܝܪܗ

place.desc: A region west of the Caspian Sea, encompassing the modern country of Azerbaijan and the provinces of northwest Iran.
A village on the Euphrates north of Mabbug and south of Samosata.
A port city between Beirut and Tripolis.

place.placeName: Ḥiṣn Maslama Ibn ʿAbd al-Malik — ܚܣܢ ܡܣܠܡܗ ܒܢ ܥܒܕ ܐܠܡܠܟ

place.desc: A port city in Palaestina north of Gaza.
A Roman province in central Anatolia.
An Anatolian coastal region north of Antioch.
A second "St. Barbara" monastery mentioned by Barsoum in his description of St. Barbara.

place.placeName: Mor Yuḥanon Ṭayoyo — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܘܚܢܢ ܛܝܝܐ

place.desc: A Roman province of coastal Anatolia with its capital at Tarsos.
A Roman province of coastal Anatolia with its capital at Anazarbos.
A ruined monastery attested near Ḥomṣ

desc.quote: Located on the Tigris, south of modern Baghdad.

place.desc: The mountain where the village Mlīkh is located.
A city in Cappadocia, modern Kayseri.
A large inland sea north of Iran and east of Adharbayjān.
A city at the confluence of the Euphrates and the Khabur rivers.
A city across the Bosphorus from Constantinople, the site of an ecumenical council in 451.
A city in western Asia Minor.
An ancient and medieval city 70 km north of Aleppo.
A village in modern Syria near the Euphrates.
A diocese of the Church of the East, whose bishop was a suffragan of the Metropolitan of Beth Huzaye.

place.placeName: Mor Behnam Hermitage — ܚܒܝ̈ܫܝܬܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܒܗܢܡ (ܘܡܪܝ ܝܘܣܦ)
place.desc: A hermitage in the hills above Dayr al-Zaʿfarān.

desc.quote: Syriac Darmsuq and Arabic Dimashq. City in Syria and the seat at present of the Syr. Orth. Patriarchate.

place.desc: A Roman city between Mardin and Nisibis.

desc.quote: Monastery and village in Ṭur ʿAbdin.

place.desc: A medieval region east of Edessa and north of Harran, mentioned in Arabic chronicles from the Crusader period.

desc.quote: A Syr. Orth. monastery dedicated to Mar Ḥnonyo (Arab. Ḥanānyā) located outside Mardin, and the seat of the patriarchate from 1293 until after World War I.

place.placeName: St. Cosmas Church — ܥܕܬܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܩܘܙܡܐ

place.desc: A vilayet of the Ottoman Empire created from a portion of Diyarbakir vilayet.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Abay — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܒܝ
place.desc: A monastery near Qeleth in Ṭur ʿAbdin.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Abrohom — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܒܪܗܡ ܐܘ ܡܪܝ ܗܒܝܠ

placeName.reg: ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܒܪܗܡ ܐܘ ܡܪܝ ܗܒܝܠ

place.placeName: ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܐܒܪܗܡ ܐܘ ܡܪܝ ܗܒܝܠ
place.desc: A monastery near Midyat in Ṭur ʿAbdin.

place.placeName: Dayro d-Mor Yaʿqub — ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܝܥܩܘܒ ܚܒܝܫܝܐ
place.desc: A monastery near Ṣalaḥ in Ṭur ʿAbdin, seat of the Syrian Orthodox patriarchate of Ṭur ʿAbdin from 1365.
A monastery overlooking Dayr al-Zaʿfarān outside Mardin, dedicated to the Virgin Mary and St. Theodore.
A Roman town in the province of Isauria.
A town west of the Euphrates, north of Aleppo, and northeast of Cyrrhus.
A town in northern Iraq north of Alqosh and southeast of Zakho.

desc.quote: Ancient city situated on the west bank of the Middle Euphrates, today known as Tell Ṣāliḥiyya, some 90 km. south-east of Dayr al-Zor, Syria.

place.desc: A city of Mesopotamia, the capital of the ancient kingdom of Osrhoene, modern Urfa.
A Roman province on the west bank of the Euphrates from above Samosata to Circesium.

desc.quote: City in upper Mesopotamia.

place.desc: A Roman town in Cilicia II near the head of the Gulf of Iskenderun.
The western major river of Mesopotamia, flowing from eastern Turkey to the Persian Gulf.

desc.quote: A region in southwestern Iran, often identified as the heartland of the Iranian people.

place.desc: A city in New Jersey, USA.
A portion of the city of Rome.
A city in Cilicia, a provincial capital of the Roman Empire and for a time the capital of the Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia.

desc.quote: The region in the southeast corner of Turkey dominated by the mountains Cilo Dag (4170 m.) and Sat Dag (3810 m.), and the highlands around them, cut by the gorges of the Great Zab River and its tributaries.
Classical Adiabene, Syriac Ḥadyāb, refers to the region between the Upper and Lower Zab rivers, from the Tigris in the west to Mt. Ṣalāḥ al-dīn (= Mt. Pirmum) in the east.
